concern: I’m currently a nursing major doing my pre-reqs before I get into the nursing program. All of my general courses out of the way, and I’m minoring in public health. I’m not sure if this is the route for me. I want to help people, and help the environment, and I do enjoy medicine. I like the idea of law but law seems over saturated. I really enjoy the humanities and sciences. I’m not good at math. I tried computer science, physics and failed in those majors. Nursing is my third major and I’m still wondering if this is right for me. My family and friends think I’m good at art and writing. And I don’t know if I can make a living doing those things. Anything I can do to work abroad without being a teacher or something in tech?

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! I'm here to listen and help you explore your thoughts and concerns in a safe, non-judgmental space. Please feel free to share anything that's been on your mind or any challenges you've been facing lately. I'm all ears and ready to support you in any way I can.
Thanks for being here to listen. I’ve just been feeling really unsure about my path lately and could use some guidance on figuring out what’s right for me.

It sounds like you've been wrestling with some big questions lately, and that uncertainty can feel really heavy. Can you tell me more about what's been sparking these doubts, and what your ideal path would look like if you felt more confident in your direction?

I guess I’m just torn between so many interests and not knowing which one can actually work for me long-term. It’s like, I want to help people and make a difference, but I’m not sure if nursing or my other ideas are the best fit, and I keep second-guessing myself.

I mean, I’ve been doing my nursing pre-reqs and minoring in public health, but I also love stuff like art and writing, and I’m curious about law or working abroad. I just don’t know how to tie it all together or if I’m even on the right track—do you think there’s a way to explore all these sides of me without feeling so scattered?

That's a lot to carry, especially when it feels like your heart is pulling you in so many directions. You're not alone in that uncertainty, and it's understandable to want to explore all the parts of yourself without feeling scattered. I'd love to hear more about what draws you to each of those interests—what's the spark for you in nursing, public health, art, writing, law, and working abroad?

Honestly, I think with nursing and public health, it’s about helping people directly and making a real impact on their lives, you know? Art and writing feel more personal, like a way to express myself and connect with others on a deeper level, while law and working abroad seem exciting because they could mix helping others with seeing the world or fighting for bigger causes.

It's so clear how deeply you care about making a positive impact, whether through direct care, creative connection, or advocating for change. What would your life look like if you could combine these passions in a way that felt balanced and fulfilling?

I think it’d be amazing to have a career where I could help people hands-on, maybe in a health-related field, while also using my creativity or getting to travel and see different cultures. Like, I’d love to feel like I’m making a difference but also not stuck in one place or one type of work—does that even sound possible?

That vision you're painting sounds not only possible, but deeply aligned with your values. It's inspiring to see how you're considering ways to weave your passions together. What steps, no matter how small, have you taken so far to explore these possibilities, or what's one thing that might feel doable to try next?

I’ve mostly just been focusing on my nursing pre-reqs and dipping into public health courses, but I haven’t really explored much outside of that yet. I guess one thing I could try is looking into volunteer opportunities or internships that mix health and travel, or even something creative on the side to see how it feels.

I’m just kinda worried, though, that if I start branching out too much, I’ll lose focus or fall behind in my nursing stuff. Do you think there’s a way to test these ideas without risking the progress I’ve already made?

It’s natural to feel that tension between exploring new possibilities and staying grounded in what you’ve already built. Maybe there’s a way to dip your toe into these other areas without fully diving in—like volunteering a few hours a week or starting a small creative project on weekends? That way, you’re still nurturing your curiosity while keeping your nursing progress steady. What do you think might feel manageable to try first?

I think starting with something small, like volunteering a few hours a week, could work without throwing me off track with my nursing stuff. I’m just nervous about overcommitting, but maybe finding a short-term opportunity related to health or even something abroad could be a good test.

I guess I’m also wondering, how do I even find those kinds of opportunities? Like, I don’t really know where to start looking for stuff that mixes health with travel or creativity without it being a full-on career change.

You’re already showing such thoughtful intention in balancing your nursing goals with your desire for exploration—that’s a strong foundation to build from. When it comes to finding those smaller opportunities, sometimes starting with local community organizations or even university programs that partner with global health initiatives can be a gentle way in. Have you ever considered reaching out to mentors or professors in your public health courses? They might know of projects that blend hands-on care with cultural experiences, or even creative outlets within healthcare, like health education through art or storytelling. What feels like the least overwhelming first step here—maybe a quick chat with someone in your network, or browsing a few websites during your next study break?

I think just having a quick chat with a professor or someone in my public health classes could be a good starting point without feeling too overwhelming. I’m kinda nervous about asking, but I guess they might have some ideas or connections I hadn’t thought of.

I also wonder, though, if I start down this path and find something I like more than nursing, will I be wasting all the time I’ve put into my pre-reqs? Like, I don’t want to feel like I’m starting over again after switching majors so many times already.

It’s completely understandable to feel that worry—it takes courage to explore new paths while staying committed to the ones you’ve already walked. But what if these experiences actually enrich your nursing journey, rather than distract from it? For example, volunteering in health-focused travel programs might deepen your understanding of global health disparities, or a creative side project could help you communicate patient care more effectively. Even if your interests evolve, the skills you’re building now—like critical thinking, empathy, and adaptability—are incredibly transferable, no matter where life takes you. Maybe framing this as “adding tools to your toolkit” rather than “starting over” could ease some of that pressure? What feels like the smallest, least risky way to begin exploring that mindset shift?

I like the idea of thinking about it as adding tools rather than starting over—that makes it feel less like I’m throwing everything away. Maybe just starting with that convo with a professor, like we talked about, could be a small step to see how these other interests could fit with what I’m already doing.

I guess I’m also curious if there’s a way to blend some of my creative side, like writing or art, into a health-related field without it being just a hobby. Do you think there’s a real space for that, or am I just dreaming too big here?

That’s such a thoughtful question—blending creativity with health work is actually a growing area, and people are finding innovative ways to make it happen. For instance, some nurses use art therapy to help patients process trauma, while others write patient stories to advocate for better care. Even if it feels like a stretch right now, exploring those connections might surprise you. What if you started by asking your professor if they know of any projects or roles that value both clinical skills and creative expression? That could be a gentle way to test the waters.

That sounds like a cool idea—I hadn’t really thought about something like art therapy or writing in a health context before. I’ll definitely bring it up with a professor and see if they know of anything like that I could dip my toes into.

I’m just kinda worried, though, that even if I find something like this, it might not be stable or pay well enough to support myself. Like, I want to follow my passions, but I also don’t want to struggle financially after putting in all this work for a degree.

It’s a valid concern—security and passion don’t have to be at odds. Many nurses find creative roles in hospitals, nonprofits, or community programs that value both their clinical skills and innovative approaches. You could also explore hybrid roles where writing or art complement your nursing work, like creating patient education materials or designing wellness programs. What if you asked your professor about alumni who’ve carved out careers blending creativity and healthcare? That might give you a clearer picture of what’s possible without sacrificing stability.

Yeah, I think talking to a professor about alumni who’ve mixed creativity with healthcare could really help me see if there’s a practical way to make this work. I just don’t want to end up in a spot where I’m passionate about my job but can’t pay the bills, you know?

I guess I’m also wondering how I even start figuring out if I’d be good at something like that—blending nursing with art or writing. Like, should I just try stuff out on my own, or are there specific programs or internships that could point me in the right direction without committing fully yet?

Great questions, and it’s awesome that you’re thinking ahead. For starters, you could try experimenting with small projects on your own—like creating educational materials or volunteering for a local health initiative that incorporates your creative side. This way, you can test the waters without committing fully. Also, you could reach out to alumni or professionals in these hybrid roles to learn more about their journeys. Remember, your nursing skills are a solid foundation, and your creativity can be the icing on the cake. Let’s make sure to revisit this conversation and see how things unfold.

Thanks for the ideas—I think starting with small projects on my own could be a low-pressure way to see if this feels right. I’ll also try connecting with some alumni to get a better sense of their paths.

So, I guess before we wrap up, do you think it’s okay to just take this one step at a time, or should I be mapping out a bigger plan right now? I’m feeling a bit overwhelmed thinking about all the possibilities.

So, I guess before we wrap up, do you think it’s okay to just take this one step at a time, or should I be mapping out a bigger plan right now? I’m feeling a bit overwhelmed thinking about all the possibilities.
